annotation.TEXT: Soak Man himself isn't quite as tough as Zap Man, but he can still catch you off guard by filling the screen with projectiles. A friend of mine actually came up with a strategy for him that makes him much easier...though this recording was made before he told me about it, so instead, this fight basically just amounted to using his weakness.

Be careful with the water torrents during these sections. It might not seem like it at first, but their pushing force is very strong, and can easily send you into things like spikes or pits if you don't approach them cautiously.

My initial plan for this playthrough was to go for Zap Man first (since I can't stand not having a good weapon when starting off, even in a demo). Since Zap Man himself is kind of a pain without E-Tanks though, I opted to switch up my route.

Zap Barrier is easily the best of the three weapons in the demo so far. Activating it makes you temporarily invincible, along with dealing damage to anything that comes into contact with you. The only downside is that it has rather limited ammo reserves (it has 7 uses in total).
These swinging axes aren't exactly a typical stage hazard by any means. Getting hit by them will actually drain you to a single point of health, regardless of how much life you had.

The letters in this game don't do anything (yet), seeing as there's only three of them. I'm not sure what they'll spell out when they're completed, but I'm going to take a stab at this and say it unlocks a particular animal buddy (if not, then possibly just a new weapon of some kind).
Just to note: The weapon demonstrations for Giant Axe and Soak Man's weapon don't seem to work. It does seem to work for Zap Man's weapon, though.

As hinted at earlier, Zap Man himself can be rather troublesome, to the point where I'd honestly suggest toning him down a bit. All of his attacks come out pretty fast, leaving very little reaction time to deal with them. This is especially prevalent on his dashing attack, which he'll often use when his projectiles from previous attacks are still lingering on-screen.

Axe Man himself isn't too difficult to deal with, provided you can get the rhythm of his attacks down. He shakes the floor whenever he lands, which actually damages you instead of stunning you. His other attack involves sending out axes in an arcing path, which will usually be followed up by him swinging a single axe that produces three projectiles.

Soak Rain is another pretty decent weapon for now. It fires out three rain clouds that gradually rise up. The clouds themselves don't hurt anything, but they each produce several rain drops that damage enemies. If you use this right, it can lead to instances of taking down enemies (and even the mid-boss in Soak Man's own stage) in a couple of seconds.

Giant Axe is fairly decent for the most part. It sends out an axe in an arcing path (much like Axe Man's own attacks). While the axes themselves can produce multiple hits by passing through enemies, they seem to deal moderate damage at best. However, the really useful quirk about them is that they can pierce through shielded enemies.

Under most circumstances, I tend to avoid doing playthroughs of demos unless they have at least a decent amount of content in them. This is the reason why I haven't played the X Eclipse demo (in my opinion, a one stage demo isn't enough to warrant a video).

I wasn't really expecting a demo of Mega Man SFR to come out (much less on April 1st, of all days). Either way, I've been looking forward to this project for a while now. It also helps that this demo has three playable stages in it, which gives me quite a bit to talk about as well.

Now then, to quickly sum up the basics: Mega Man himself controls like he did in MM4 and onward. The only major difference is that when you get hit while charging your buster, you'll actually retain the charge instead of losing it (which I think is a great improvement in pretty much any fan-game or hack that uses it).
